Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of a crawling youth with bald head, likely Harpocrates, and side lock. Mould-made and solid. Made from two halves, joined together. Red-brown organic Nile silt fabric.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Solid terracotta figurine of a squatting Harpokrates figure with parallel from Memphis (Petrie Museum UC47797) and unprovenanced Ptolemaic parallel (Török 1995, no.221bis). Also resembles the character being trampled by Harpocrates (as a Macedonian cavalryman) in some late 4th to early 3rd century BC figure groups known from Naukratis (Paris, Louvre Museum E20831; Dunand 1990, 214-5, no.581; Louvre Museum, Paris E20831; Museum of Fine Arts, Boston 86.410; Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge GR.11.1885, GR.10.1885; Bailey 2008, no.3547, British Museum GR1973,0501.58 and elsewhere, such as Tell el Maskhuta (Abdalla Ali 1991, pl.VI, no.62.), Athribis (Myśliwiec 2009, pl.4.1), Alexandria (Breccia 1930, 69-70, pl.98, 2), Tanis (Dunand 1990, 215, no.582b) and unprovenanced (Bayer Niemeier 1988, pl.90, nos. 498, 514- 515; Fjeldhagen 131, no.114; Phillipp 1972, no.43, pl.38; Vogt 1924, 61- 2, pl.98.2; Weber 1914, 336-7, pl.31).
